title: Man who ‘held family hostage on farm for 9 years’ was former next-door neighbour
text:
The old home of Josef B in Hasselt, Netherlands on the left and the home of the family held captive on the right (Picture: Nick Edwards/Daily Mail)

An Austrian carpenter accused of locking a family of six inside a farmhouse for almost a decade used to be their next-door neighbour, it has emerged.

Josef Brunner, 58, has been arrested by Dutch police for allegedly keeping pensioner Geert van Dorsten and his five adult children locked in rooms and in a basement of a remote property as they ‘waited for the world to end’.

Police said the family were held in a tiny ‘secret’ makeshift room and some believed they were the only people on Earth.

Today, local news reports claim some of the children captured – aged between 18 and 25 – have lost the ability to speak.

The family were only discovered after eldest son Jan Zon van Dorsten, 25, walked to a nearby bar in the town of Ruinerwold, Netherlands, on Sunday and asked for help.

Advertisement

Officers found his four brothers and sisters along with their father in a room hidden behind a staircase.

A former neighbour of the family has now come forward and says that their alleged captor used to live next door to them.

Jan Zon van Dorsten, 25, raised the alarm about the way his family were living (Picture: Facebook)

The remote farmhouse where the family were kept (Picture: AFP)

The family are understood to have been kept in a small, enclosed space behind a staircase in the remote farmhouse (Picture: AFP)

The family are understood to have been hidden away in Ruinerwold, Drenthe, for nine years

Sandra Soer, who lives in Hasselt, south of Ruinerwold, told MailOnline Brunner lived next door to the ‘off-grid’ family for a brief period before they all moved.

She said: ‘The majority of children born in this house. There was no midwife involved. They all did that themselves.

‘A daughter had a birthday on the same day as my daughter. They often played together. But only in their back garden. The children never went out on the street or came to our house. You’d often see them climbing in the trees.

‘The children didn’t go to a school in the neighborhood. But I saw them leave every morning with a bag with their father, so I assumed they were going to school somewhere else.’

Brunner only lived in the street for a very short time and Sandra said she assumed he knew the van Dorsten family – who she described as reclusive – because shortly after moving in they removed a fence that separated their back gardens.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The children’s mother died in mysterious circumstances in 2004 – but by this time Brunner had already moved out, Sandra said.

She added: ‘One day Geert came and told me that his wife had just died of colon cancer. Nobody knew she was that sick. No one knew when she was buried.

‘Not long after, the family had left but they continued to pay the rent for the house. One of the daughters lived in the house for a while. I think she was sixteen. But a short time later when someone from the housing association came round, the house was vacated.’

The father was said to have a shared passion for woodwork with his alleged captor, and used to make toys, while Brunner built wooden canoes.

One of Jan’s posts on Facebook – which he began using again in June after nine years of silence online (Picture: Facebook)

Jan told a local Ruinerwold barman he wanted to end the way he and his siblings were living (Picture: Facebook)

Sandra said: ‘I was surprised that they had remained in contact and even more shocked when I heard what had happened to Geert and his family.

‘Josef was never friendly. He never said hello. He wasn’t friends with anybody.

‘He never had a wife. He never had a girlfriend. He would never go to a bar. He was just mysterious.

‘When they left, I didn’t know where they’d gone.

‘It was a total surprise to me that they were still in touch with Josef. This is a very sad situation for the family.’

Advertisement

It has now emerged that Geert and the family owned a toy shop in the village in Zwartsluis to the west of Hasselt whey the family lived for a short period before moving to the farmhouse in Ruinerwold.

The house has now been sealed off by police as investigations continue.

Police said that the father and five children are all receiving medical treatment.

Chris Westerbeek, owner of the café De Kastelein, said eldest son Jan drank five pints before telling him how he had not been outside in nine years and wanted to end the way he and his siblings were living.

In the months before raising the alarm, Jan had posted sporadically on social media accounts, beginning in June this year.

On his public profile on Facebook it shows he used the platform for several years until 2010, when he posted saying that he had moved to Ruinerwold.

He no longer posted on the site until June when he announced he was working as an online store manager at Creconat, located in Meppel, around four miles away.

Jan posted pictures of himself ‘in nature’ to his social media accounts (Picture: Jan Zon van Dorsten/Instagram)

Police have now sealed off the house and surrounding area (Picture: Alamy)

According to De Telegraaf, Creconat is associated with a timber company called Native Creative Economy, also based in Meppel, which is owned by Brunner.

Café owner Chris – who called police – told Dutch broadcaster RTV Drenthe Jan had been in three times before but on his last visit told him he could not go home.

Advertisement

He said: ‘You could see he had no idea where he was or what he was doing. He said he had run away and that he urgently needed help.’

Neighbours of the remote farm, which was set back 200 yards from the nearest road, told RTV Drenthe that Brunner was a private man who never allowed visitors inside the house.

Pictures show it was surrounded by trees and a perimeter fence.

The neighbours said they had been suspicious as he would go back and forth from the house to his workshop 15 miles away in a Volvo every day without speaking to anyone.

He would make weekly visits to a local Lidl supermarket where it is believed he would stock up on supplies for the family.

A man who owns a building business next door said: ‘I have known him for about seven years, but I really know very little about him.

‘I would see him every day, but he will just say hello. I could never have imagined that he had another home and six people were in there. He never ever talked about friends or anybody.’

He added: ‘I was curious because he would buy something like 50 toilet rolls and huge boxes of food once a week and then drive off with them.’

Investigators admit they are deeply puzzled by the case and are still working to answer key questions.

Officers have had difficulty understanding the victims as some of their speech was ‘incomprehensible’.

Initially it was thought the family lived off the land and animals but reports now suggest their alleged captor brought them food from Lidl (Picture: Alamy)

The father and his five adult children are now receiving medical treatment (Picture: Alamy)

Police said a number of questions remain unanswered (Picture: ANP)

It is understood they slept and ate on the floor in a ‘small, enclosed space’ with no natural light.

Police said the family were not malnourished and looked ‘normal’.

Local mayor Roger de Groot told reporters on Tuesday: ‘I understand there are a lot of questions. We have many too.

‘The police are investigating all possible scenarios.’

Brunner, who has gained the nickname ‘Josef the Austrian’ locally, will appear in court today.

He has been charged with deprivation of liberty and prejudicing the health of others.

description: Austrian carpenter Josef Brunner, 58, is accused of locking a pensioner and his five adult children in a remote farmhouse to 'wait for the world to end'.
